<h level="4" i="4">====Noun====</h>
<template lineStart="1"><title>en-noun</title></template>
<template lineStart="1"><title>examples-right</title><part><name index="1"/><value>
The word ''inventory'' may be pronounced with four syllables (/ˈɪn.vən.tɔ.ɹi/) or only three (/ɪnˈvɛn.tɹi/).
<br><br>
The word ''island'' is six letters long; the ''s'' has never been pronounced but was added under the influence of ''isle''.
<br><br>
[[File:ASL_1@Sternum-FingerBack.jpg||200px]]<br>The word ''me'' signed in American Sign Language.
</value></part></template>

# The smallest unit of language which has a particular meaning and can be expressed by itself; the smallest [[discrete]], [[meaningful]] unit of language. <template><title>qualifier</title><part><name index="1"/><value>Contrast ''[[morpheme]]''.</value></part></template> <template><title>defdate</title><part><name index="1"/><value>from 10th c.</value></part></template>
#* '''1986''', David Barrat, ''Media Sociology'' (ISBN 041505110X), page 112:
#*: The '''word''', whether written or spoken, does not look like or sound like its meaning — it does not resemble its signified. We only connect the two because we have learnt the code — language. Without such knowledge, 'Maggie' would just be a meaningless pattern of shapes or sounds.
#* '''2009''', Jack Fitzgerald, ''Viva La Evolucin'' (ISBN 055719833X), page 233:
#*: Brian and Abby signed the '''word''' ''clothing'', in which the thumbs brush down the chest as though something is hanging there. They both spoke the '''word''' ''clothing''. Brian then signed the '''word''' for ''change'', <template><title>...</title></template>
#* <template><title>quote-magazine</title><part><name>date</name>=<value>2013-06-14</value></part><part><name>author</name>=<value>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/profile/sam-leith Sam Leith] </value></part><part><name>volume</name>=<value>189</value></part><part><name>issue</name>=<value>1</value></part><part><name>page</name>=<value>37</value></part><part><name>magazine</name>=<value><template><title>w</title><part><name index="1"/><value>The Guardian Weekly</value></part></template> </value></part><part><name>title</name>=<value>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/books/2013/may/23/holy-shit-history-swearing-mohr Where the profound meets the profane] </value></part><part><name>passage</name>=<value>Swearing doesn't just mean what we now understand by "dirty words". It is entwined, in social and linguistic history, with the other sort of swearing: vows and oaths. Consider for a moment the origins of almost any '''word''' we have for bad language – "profanity", "curses", "oaths" and "swearing" itself.</value></part></template>
## The smallest discrete unit of spoken language which has a particular meaning, composed of one or more [[phoneme]]s and one or more [[morpheme]]s.
##* '''1894''', Alex. R. Mackwen, ''The Samaritan Passover'', in ''Littell's Living Age'', series 6, volume 1:
##*: Then all was silent save the voice of the high priest, whose '''words''' grew louder and louder, <template><title>...</title></template>
##* <template><title>quote-book</title><part><name>year</name>=<value>1898</value></part><part><name>author</name>=<value><template><title>w</title><part><name index="1"/><value>Winston Churchill (novelist)</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>Winston Churchill</value></part></template></value></part><part><name>title</name>=<value><template><title>w</title><part><name index="1"/><value>The Celebrity</value></part></template></value></part><part><name>chapter</name>=<value>4 </value></part><part><name>passage</name>=<value>Mr. Cooke at once began a tirade against the residents of Asquith for permitting a sandy and generally disgraceful condition of the roads. So roundly did he vituperate the inn management in particular, and with such a loud flow of '''words''', that I trembled lest he should be heard on the veranda.</value></part></template>
## The smallest discrete unit of written language which has a particular meaning, composed of one or more [[letter]]s or [[symbol]]s and one or more [[morpheme]]s.
##* <template><title>RQ:Shakespeare Hamlet</title></template>, act 2, scene 2:
##*: Polonius: What do you read, my lord?
##*: Hamlet: '''Words''', '''words''', '''words'''.
##* '''2003''', Jan Furman, ''Toni Morrison's Song of Solomon: A Casebook'' (ISBN 0195146352), page 194:
##*: The name was a confused gift of love from her father, who could not read the '''word''' but picked it out of the Bible for its visual shape, <template><title>...</title></template>
##* '''2009''', Stanislas Dehaene, ''Reading in the Brain: The New Science of How We Read'' (ISBN 1101152400):
##*: Well-meaning academics even introduced spelling absurdities such as the “s” in the '''word''' “island,” a misguided Renaissance attempt to restore the etymology of the [unrelated] Latin word ''insula''.
## A discrete, meaningful unit of language which is approved by some [[authority]].
##* '''1896''', <template><title>w</title><part><name index="1"/><value>Israel Zangwill</value></part></template>, ''Without Prejudice'', page 21:
##*: “Ain’t! How often am I to tell you ain’t ain’t a '''word'''?”
##* '''1999''', Linda Greenlaw, ''The Hungry Ocean'', Hyperion, page 11:
##*: ''Fisherwoman'' isn’t even a '''word'''. It’s not in the dictionary.
## A [[sequence]] of [[letters]] or characters, or [[sound]]s, which (does not necessarily belong to a language or have a meaning, but which) is considered as a [[discrete]] [[entity]].
##* '''1974''', ''Thinking Goes to School: Piaget's Theory in Practice'' (ISBN 0199839077), page 183:
##*: In still another variation, the nonsense '''word''' is presented and the teacher asks, "What sound was in the beginning of the word?" "In the middle?" and so on. The child should always respond with the phoneme; he should not use letter labels.
##* '''2003''', ''How To Do Everything with Your Tablet PC'' (ISBN 0072227710), page 278:
##*: I wrote a nonsense '''word''', "umbalooie," in the Input Panel's Writing Pad. Input Panel converted it to "cembalos" and displayed it in the Text Preview pane.
##* '''2006''', ''Scribal Habits and Theological Influences in the Apocalypse'' (ISBN 3161491122), page 141:
##*: Here the scribe has dropped the με from καθημενος, thereby creating the nonsense word καθηνος.
##* '''2013''', ''The Cognitive Neuropsychology of Language'' (ISBN 1317859979), page 91:
##*: If M. V. has sustained impairment to a phonological output process common to reading and repetition, we might anticipate that her mispronunciations will partially reflect the underlying phonemic form of the nonsense '''word'''.
# Something which is like such a unit of language:
## <template><title>context</title><part><name index="1"/><value>telegraphy</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>en</value></part></template> A unit of [[text]] equivalent to five [[character]]s and one [[space]]. <template><title>defdate</title><part><name index="1"/><value>from 19th c.</value></part></template>
## <template><title>context</title><part><name index="1"/><value>computing</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>en</value></part></template> A fixed-size group of [[bit]]s handled as a unit by a machine (on many [[16-bit]] machines, 16 bits or two [[byte]]s). <template><title>defdate</title><part><name index="1"/><value>from 20th c.</value></part></template>
## <template><title>context</title><part><name index="1"/><value>computer science</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>en</value></part></template> A [[finite]] [[string]] which is [[not]] a [[command]] or [[operator]]. <template><title>defdate</title><part><name index="1"/><value>from 20th or 21st c.</value></part></template>
## <template><title>context</title><part><name index="1"/><value>group theory</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>en</value></part></template> A [[group]] [[element]], expressed as a [[product]] of group elements.
# The fact or act of [[speaking]], as opposed to taking [[action]]. <template><title>defdate</title><part><name index="1"/><value>from 9th c.</value></part></template>
#* '''1811''', <template><title>w</title><part><name index="1"/><value>Jane Austen</value></part></template>, ''<template><title>w</title><part><name index="1"/><value>Sense and Sensibility</value></part></template>'':
#*: <template><title>...</title></template> she believed them still so very much attached to each other, that they could not be too sedulously divided in '''word''' and deed on every occasion.
#* '''2004''', Richard Williams, ''The Guardian'', 8 Sep 2004:
#*: As they fell apart against Austria, England badly needed someone capable of leading by '''word''' and example.
# <template><title>context</title><part><name index="1"/><value>now</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>rare</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value>_</value></part><part><name index="4"/><value>outside certain phrases</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>en</value></part></template> Something which has been said; a [[comment]], [[utterance]]; [[speech]]. <template><title>defdate</title><part><name index="1"/><value>from 10th c.</value></part></template>
#* '''1611''', ''Bible'', Authorized Version, <template><title>w</title><part><name index="1"/><value>Gospel of Matthew</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>Matthew</value></part></template> XXVI.75:

#* '''2011''', <template><title>w</title><part><name index="1"/><value>David Bellos</value></part></template>, ''Is That a Fish in Your Ear?'', Penguin 2012, page 126:

#* '''1592''', William Shakespeare, ''<template><title>w</title><part><name index="1"/><value>Richard III (play)</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>Richard III</value></part></template>'':
#*: Our ancient '''word''' of courage, fair Saint George, inspire us with the spleen of fiery dragons!
#* '''1647''' (published),  John Fletcher and William Rowley, ''<template><title>w</title><part><name index="1"/><value>The Maid in the Mill</value></part></template>'' (published in the first Beaumont and Fletcher folio), scene 3:
#*: I have the '''word''' : sentinel, do thou stand; <template><title>...</title></template>
#: ''[[mum's the word|mum's the '''word''']]''

#* '''1599''', Ben Jonson, ''<template><title>w</title><part><name index="1"/><value>Every Man out of His Humour</value></part></template>'':

<h level="5" i="5">=====Usage notes=====</h>
* <template><title>sense</title><part><name index="1"/><value>distinct unit of language</value></part></template> In English and other space-delimited languages, it is customary to treat "word" as referring to any sequence of characters delimited by spaces. However, this is not applicable to languages such as [[Chinese]] and [[Japanese]], which are normally written without spaces, or to languages such as [[Vietnamese]], which are written with a space between each [[syllable]].

<template lineStart="1"><title>wikipedia</title><part><name index="1"/><value>word (computing)</value></part></template>
* <template><title>sense</title><part><name index="1"/><value>computing</value></part></template> The size (length) of a word, while being fixed in a particular machine or processor family design, can be different in different designs, for many reasons. See <template><title>w</title><part><name index="1"/><value>Word (computing)</value></part></template> for a full [[explanation]].

<h level="5" i="6">=====Quotations=====</h>
* '''1897''', Ouida, ''The New Woman'', in ''An Altruist and Four Essays'', page 239:
*: But every '''word''', whether written or spoken, which urges the woman to antagonism against the man, every '''word''' which is written or spoken to try and make of her a hybrid, self-contained opponent of men, makes a rift in the lute to which the world looks for its sweetest music.
* '''2011''', John Lehew (senior), ''The Encouragement of Peter'' (ISBN 1615074708), page 108:
*: In what sense is God's Word living? No other '''word''', whether written or spoken, has the power that the Bible has to change lives.
* <template><title>seemoreCites</title><part><name>lang</name>=<value>en</value></part></template>

<h level="4" i="9">====Verb====</h>
<template lineStart="1"><title>en-verb</title></template>

# <template><title>lb</title><part><name index="1"/><value>en</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>transitive</value></part></template> To [[say]] or [[write]] (something) using particular words; to [[phrase]] (something).
#: ''I’m not sure how to '''word''' this letter to the council.''
# <template><title>lb</title><part><name index="1"/><value>en</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>transitive</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value>obsolete</value></part></template> To [[flatter]] with words, to [[cajole]].
#* '''1607''', William Shakespeare, ''Anthony and Cleopatra'', act 5, scene 2: 
#*: He '''words''' me, girls, he '''words''' me, that I should not / be noble to myself.
# <template><title>lb</title><part><name index="1"/><value>en</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>transitive</value></part></template> To [[ply]] or [[overpower]] with words.
#* '''1621''' November 30, James Howell, letter to Francis Bacon, from Turin: 
#*: <template><title>...</title></template> if one were to be '''worded''' to death, Italian is the fittest Language [for that task]
#* '''1829''' April, ''Webster's Dictionary'', in ''The North American Review'', volume 28, page 438: 
#*: <template><title>...</title></template> if a man were to be worded to death, or stoned to death by words, the High-Dutch were the fittest [language for that task].
# <template><title>lb</title><part><name index="1"/><value>en</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>transitive</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value>rare</value></part></template> To [[conjure]] with a word.
#* <template><title>circa</title><part><name index="1"/><value>1645–1715</value></part></template> <template><title>w</title><part><name index="1"/><value>Robert South</value></part></template>, ''Sermon on Psalm XXXIX. 9'':
#*: Against him <template><title>...</title></template> who could '''word''' heaven and earth out of nothing, and can when he pleases '''word''' them into nothing again.
#* '''1994''', ''Liminal Postmodernisms''/''Postmodern Studies'', volume 8, page 162:
#*: "Postcolonialism" might well be another linguistic construct, desperately begging for a referent that will never show up, simply because it never existed on its own and was literally '''worded''' into existence by the very term that pretends to be born from it.
#* '''2013''', Carla Mae Streeter, ''Foundations of Spirituality: The Human and the Holy'' (ISBN 0814680712), page 92:
#*: The being of each person is '''worded''' into existence in the Word, <template><title>...</title></template>
# <template><title>lb</title><part><name index="1"/><value>en</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>intransitive</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value>archaic</value></part></template> To [[speak]], to use words; to [[converse]], to [[discourse]].
#* '''1818''', John Keats, ''Hyperion'':
#*: Thus '''wording''' timidly among the fierce: / 'O Father, I am here the simplest voice, [...]'

# <template><title>context</title><part><name index="1"/><value>slang</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>emphatic</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value>stereotypically</value></part><part><name index="4"/><value>AAVE</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>en</value></part></template> An abbreviated form of <template><title>term</title><part><name index="1"/><value>word up</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>en</value></part></template>; a statement of the acknowledgment of fact with a hint of nonchalant approval.
#* '''2004''', Shannon Holmes, ''Never Go Home Again: A Novel'', page 218:
#*: "<template><title>...</title></template> Know what I'm sayin'?" / "'''Word'''!" the other man strongly agreed. "Let's do this — "

<h level="3" i="28">===Etymology===</h>
From <template><title>etyl</title><part><name index="1"/><value>gem-pro</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>ang</value></part></template> <template><title>m</title><part><name index="1"/><value>gem-pro</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>*wurdą</value></part></template>, from <template><title>etyl</title><part><name index="1"/><value>ine-pro</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>ang</value></part></template> <template><title>m</title><part><name index="1"/><value>ine-pro</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>*werdʰo-</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value/></part><part><name index="4"/><value>word</value></part></template>, from <template><title>etyl</title><part><name index="1"/><value>ine-pro</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>ang</value></part></template> <template><title>m</title><part><name index="1"/><value>ine-pro</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>*wer-</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value/></part><part><name index="4"/><value>speak</value></part></template>; cognate with Old Frisian <template><title>term</title><part><name index="1"/><value>word</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>ofs</value></part></template>, Old Saxon <template><title>term</title><part><name index="1"/><value>word</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>osx</value></part></template>, Old Dutch <template><title>term</title><part><name index="1"/><value>wort</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>odt</value></part></template> (Dutch <template><title>term</title><part><name index="1"/><value>woord</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>nl</value></part></template>), Old High German <template><title>term</title><part><name index="1"/><value>wort</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>goh</value></part></template> (German <template><title>term</title><part><name index="1"/><value>Wort</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>de</value></part></template>), Old Norse <template><title>term</title><part><name index="1"/><value>orð</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>non</value></part></template> (Icelandic <template><title>term</title><part><name index="1"/><value>orð</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>is</value></part></template>, Swedish <template><title>term</title><part><name index="1"/><value>ord</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>sv</value></part></template>), Gothic <template><title>term</title><part><name>sc</name>=<value>Goth</value></part><part><name index="1"/><value>𐍅𐌰𐌿𐍂𐌳</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>got</value></part></template>. The Proto-Indo-European root is also the source of Latin <template><title>term</title><part><name index="1"/><value>verbum</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>la</value></part></template>, Lithuanian <template><title>term</title><part><name index="1"/><value>vardas</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>lt</value></part></template>, and, more distantly, of Ancient Greek <template><title>term</title><part><name index="1"/><value>εἴρω</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value/></part><part><name index="3"/><value>I say</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>grc</value></part></template> and Old Slavonic <template><title>term</title><part><name index="1"/><value/></part><part><name index="2"/><value/></part><part><name index="3"/><value>to swear</value></part><part><name>tr</name>=<value>rotiti sę</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>cu</value></part></template> (Russian <template><title>term</title><part><name index="1"/><value>ротиться</value></part><part><name>tr</name>=<value>rotit’sja</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value/></part><part><name index="3"/><value>to vow</value></part><part><name>lang</name>=<value>ru</value></part></template>).
